definition:
Let $K$ be an of $\mathbb{Q}$ contained in $\mathbb{C}$. A number
$\alpha \in K$ is called an *algebraic integer* of $K$ if it is the root
of a monic polynomial with coefficients in $\mathbb{Z}$, i.e., an
element of $K$ that is integral over $\mathbb{Z}$. Every algebraic
integer is an algebraic number (with $K = \mathbb{C}$), but the converse
is false.
